ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3 hrs
varied greatly from week to week.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Very interesting, thorough, and scientific.

- great subject material- end of term expectations should have been more clearly stated at the beginning-in class experiment should have been split to allow more individual time-->and for us to really understand what was going on
Overall the course covered a diverse range of interesting topics. There seemed to be a lot of "busy work" assignments. Goals and objectives were not always clear/defined.

The greatest advantage of the class is the responsiveness of the instructors to the students. The class was very interesting and the instructors did an excellent job in familiarizing us with a variety of vectors and the way research is conducted in this field.A weakness of the class was that sometimes assignments were posted late and some weeks we had to do an assignment for each class.

I enjoyed this class a lot, particularly the opportunity to be a part of a real, ongoing research project. Generally the class felt somewhat disorganized, however. It seemed like, particularly in the second half of the class, that we didn't really have many lectures. Lots of class time was spent either in lab, or doing discussion. I enjoyed both aspects of the class, but it seemed like those activities might be better suited for a discussion component of the main class. Perhaps it would be better if the class were designed with both lecture and discussion sections. That way we could have classroom time and time for lab/discussion without either one eating too much into the other.Also, while I enjoyed writing the final paper and thought it was an interesting exercise, it seemed somewhat overkill to couple it with a final exam (particularly with the two being due within a week of each other). Maybe if the paper were due earlier, or were considered the final that would work better.Finally, in terms of subject matter, it felt that we really only focused on a few vectors. Mainly we looked at sand flies, kissing bugs, mosquitoes, tsetse, and ticks. It would have been nice to cover other vectors, such as fleas, lice, bats, or rats. Also, some discussion of ecology would have been useful.

The course was really interesting and informative. However, it was slightly disorganized, emphasizing only certain disease vectors over others. Additionally, the expectations of the students in the course was a little unclear. The time spent in the tsetse lab was an invaluable learning experience.

Strengths: interesting subject matter, high teacher/student ratio, lots of opportunities to ask questions and provide feedback. Interesting laboratory component, although making it optional might be a good idea, due to differences in student backgrounds and interests.Weaknesses: not nearly enough time to do most primary lit reviews -- poor organization of assignments/deadlines. In the future, *please* post articles more than a few days prior to discussion due-dates, and make the lab manuscript write-up criteria/results available *much* earlier. The work-load was way too heavy at the end of the semester, and a bit light early in the semester. Also, I'd like to see a bit more on practical applications of material (insecticide lectures, olfaction lectures were great -- more of this type of thing, such as how traps worked or how control efforts are actually applied in the field) and less molecular biology (we spent a really long time going over antimicrobial peptides, etc.). Also, perhaps substitute the tick lecture with more on Chagas, onchocerciasis, filariasis vectors and control, etc.

This was a great class! I really learned a lot about vector biology, and I liked that there was a lab component to the course. One thing that I would have appreciated is more of a discussion about the controversy surrounding mosquito transgenesis/ paratransgenesis as disease control strategies. Also, I personally thought that there were too many guest lectures. Some of the most informative and interesting lectures that we had were given by Drs. Aksoy and Weiss. I would also say that some of the papers assigned (specifically the pop gen papers) were a little too difficult for our level.
I enjoyed the course, particularly the lab component.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Very personable and intelligent.

Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Was one of the best teachers I have had at Yale. He is very smart and knowledgeable about his subject material, but he is also very nice and relaxed. His attitude made his classroom conducive to learning.

Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Brian is a good instructor who is always responsive to emails and is available for questions/discussion. He has a firm grasp on the materials and can provide relevant real world examples.
Instructor: Brian l Weiss  He is a great instructor and fun to be around.He did a good job in explaining the material and how the lab works.He is easy to talk to and always responds to questions.
Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Brian was great and very enthusiastic. I thought he was good lecturer and fair/flexible as an instructor.
Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Extremely approachable and gave excellent lectures.
Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Friendly, good lecturer (manageable information, good powerpoints). Could work on organization skills/making requirements for assignments more clear/timely.
Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Dr. Weiss is extremely knowledgeable about vector biology. He is also approachable and friendly, and was very helpful in the lab.
Instructor: Brian l Weiss  Excellent instructor, very concerned about the students and what they were taking away from the course.
Instructor: Serap Aksoy  Very personable and intelligent.

Instructor: Serap Aksoy  She was not present during many classes. When she did lecture, she was very precise, and obviously had quite a lot of knowledge about her subject material. She was very good at fielding questions.
Instructor: Serap Aksoy  Dr. Aksoy contributes to class discussion when present. However, she was absent from a majority of class sessions.

Instructor: Serap Aksoy  She is very open-minded and she structured the class creatively. She did a great job in selecting the material, the guest lecturers and the discussion articles. She is very responsive to the students comments.
Instructor: Serap Aksoy  Dr. Aksoy was an interesting lecturer and does terrific research. It was great to have the opportunity to work with her and be a part of her research.
Instructor: Serap Aksoy  Very nice. Knows the topic extremely well and leads very open discussions.
Instructor: Serap Aksoy  Obviously knowledgeable and interested in student feedback. Powerpoints were often too long/overwhelming (not always related explicitly to what she discussed).
Instructor: Serap Aksoy  Dr. Aksoy is also clearly very knowledgeable about vector biology. I really enjoyed her lectures - she is very articulate and clear.
Instructor: Serap Aksoy  Great as well. Her scientific mind never ceased to amaze me.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Very personable and intelligent.
She was fine. She also knew a lot about the subject.
Megan provided to discussions but did not provide valuable feed back on assignments.
She was very familiar with the material and her comments were very helpful. She always responded in questions and supported the students. She was a great asset to the course.

Meagan. Meagan was generally pretty fair and very open to discussion with the class. She was always very helpful when I had questions. However, it seemed like she treated us somewhat like children. Overall I liked her, but was occasionally irked by some of her comments.
Meagan Fitzpatrick is friendly and provided good feedback on primary lit reviews.

Meagan was a fantastic TA. I was so impressed with the depth and breadth of her knowledge of vector biology. Her comments were also very helpful for our review papers, and she did a nice job helping to lead the discussions.
Wonderful TA. Extremely involved and committed. Can't imagine the course without her.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes I would highly recommend it. The teachers are so great! I am also sure that they will work out the course kinks encountered this semester.

The course is one of the best courses in the program. It is a great combination of background knowledge and current research in the field. It was very innovative and interactive. The lab component was great because it gave the opportunity to students that did not have previous lab experience to see how basic molecular methods work. Overall, I believe that we all gained a deeper understanding of how research is conducted and applied in public health.

This course looks at a number of insect disease vectors and the role of their physiology and genetics in transmission of disease-causing agents. In particular, the class integrates a small lab component and work with Dr. Aksoy's tsetse fly laboratory. Work load is moderate, with written paper reviews, classroom discussions, midterm/final exams, and a final paper.

I'd recommend the course if they are very interested in molecular biology and arthropod-borne disease. If their interest is more on a basic/applied level, probably not. We didn't learn too many vector control skills or even some basic vector biology, but learned a lot about molecular biology of vectors (particularly tsetse).

I would definitely recommend this class to any student with an interest in vector biology. It is a great introductory course, providing both basic information on insect physiology and modern research topics/ approaches to vector control
I'd recommend the course, especially if the student is interested in vector biology and environmental/ecological issues.
